author: Aamer Madhani, USA TODAY
title: Even before Chicago hospital shooting, industry was anxious about security
description: Chicago hospital shooting: Security concerns grow
content: CHICAGO – U.S. hospitals are bolstering security and safety training for their staffs in response to increasing reports of violence, security breaches and thefts on medical campuses. But Monday’s mass shooting at Chicago’s Mercy Hospital might demonstrate bot… [+4785 chars]
fulltext:
CLOSE Michael Davenport, the chief medical officer at Mercy Hospital in Chicago, says the staff of the hospital are mourning the loss of life after a man fatally shot his ex-fiancée and two other people at the hospital on Monday. (Nov. 20) AP

A police vehicle sits outside of Mercy Hospital where four people were shot and killed on Monday. Chicago Police officer Samuel Jimenez was shot and killed as he responded to a call at the hospital where Tamara O'Neal, a 38-year-old emergency room physician and Dayna Less, a 25-year-old pharmacy resident were shot by 32-year-old Juan Lopez who also died in the incident. (Photo: Scott Olson, Getty Images)

CHICAGO – U.S. hospitals are bolstering security and safety training for their staffs in response to increasing reports of violence, security breaches and thefts on medical campuses.

But Monday’s mass shooting at Chicago’s Mercy Hospital might demonstrate both the benefits and limitations of the heightened sense of alert at hospitals around the nation, health care and security experts say.

“It is really difficult for health care administrators who are trying to find a balance between being an open, caring environment and being able to protect their patients, staff and visitors,” says Alan Butler, president-elect of the board of the International Association for Healthcare Security and Safety. “The situation in Chicago highlights this.”

An emergency room doctor and pharmacy resident, along with a Chicago police officer, were killed in the Mercy shooting.

The gunman shot his ex-fiancée, Dr. Tamara O’Neal, 38, in the parking lot just outside the hospital before entering the building and killing pharmacy resident Dayna Less, 25, and Chicago police officer Samuel Jimenez, 28.

The gunman, Juan Lopez, 32, died after suffering a wound to the stomach and a self-inflicted wound to the head.

Witnesses said employees acted quickly, ushering colleagues and patients to barricade themselves in rooms or otherwise take cover. Hospital and police officials say the death toll could have been much worse if not for the quick response.

Mercy held its first ever active shooter drill just weeks before the shooting, and added classroom training and Internet instruction for workers on how to respond if a gunman opened fire at the medical center.

“With assistance from the Chicago Police Department, our emergency management team will debrief on what happened to see what lessons are to be learned from this,” said Michael Davenport, Mercy’s chief medical officer. “We anticipate there are lessons to be learned...

"We know life will never be the same for us here at Mercy and things will change.”

More: Some docs rip NRA, say #ThisIsOurLane after Chicago Mercy Hospital shooting rampage

More: Chicago hospital shooting gunman was kicked out of fire academy for bullying

More: Police officer among 4 dead in 'horrific' Chicago hospital shooting

More: Chicago Mercy Hospital shooting: Two Purdue University graduates slain in attack praised for serving others

Concerns about violence among health care providers, particularly those who work in emergency rooms, has been growing for years.

Forty-seven percent of emergency physicians say they have been physically assaulted while at work, and 60 percent of that group say those assaults occurred in the past year, according to an American College of Emergency Physicians survey of 3,500 emergency room physicians published last month.

Nearly 7 in 10 say violence has increased in the past 5 years; 25 percent report it is increasing greatly. Forty-nine percent say hospitals can do more by adding security guards, cameras, security for parking lots, metal detectors, and increasing visitor screening inside hospitals, especially in emergency departments.

“More needs to be done," says Vidor Friedman, president of the organization. "Violence in emergency departments is not only affecting medical staff, it is affecting patients."

About half of hospitals now have handheld metal detectors that can be used to help spot visitors carrying weapons, the American Society for Health Care Engineering reported in its 2018 Hospital Security Survey. That’s up from 33 percent in 2016.

Fifty-six percent of the hospitals said they were spending more to upgrade security systems or increase security staffing. And 96 percent of hospitals now have an active shooter policy on the books.

Gabor Kelen, director of emergency medicine at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, set out with colleagues to study hospital shootings following a 2010 incident at the medical center in Baltimore.

Paul Warren Pardus, 50, shot a physician, Dr. David Cohen, in the abdomen. Cohen had delivered bad news about Pardus’ mother, a patient who was undergoing cancer treatment.

Cohen survived. Pardus killed his mother before killing himself.

The sprawling Hopkins medical center, one the world’s renown hospitals, went into lockdown for about four hours.

When Kelen and colleagues reviewed more than a decade of hospital shootings, they found that the events were rare and unpredictable, and that forming effective deterrence practices is complicated.

Shooters in the 154 hospital shootings between 2000 and 2011 were most often driven by grudges, a desire to commit suicide or kill an ailing relative, or to escape from custody.

Forty-one percent of shootings on hospital grounds began or took place entirely outside the hospital building, according to a 2012 Annals of Emergency Medicine paper that Kelen co-authored.

“There’s no security that can deal with that,” Kelen told USA TODAY. “It’s so unexpected. You can’t put a security detail at every entrance at every hospital to be on the lookout for an individual storming in there.”

By: Nick Schwartz | November 21, 2018 11:50 am

The undefeated UCF Knights took care of Cincinnati on national television last weekend to earn a spot inside the Top 10 of the College Football Playoff rankings – but we could see some major changes after this weekend.

“The Game” between No. 4 Michigan and No. 10 Ohio State will have major CFP implications, and both Oklahoma and LSU will go on the road to face ranked opponents. No. 3 Notre Dame, meanwhile, will be on the West Coast for a rivalry game against potential playoff spoiler USC.

author: AP, AP
title: Ex-Hawkeye Erik Chinander's heart belongs to Cornhuskers now
description: Ex-Hawkeye Erik Chinander's heart belongs to Cornhuskers now that he's Nebraska defensive coordinator
content: In this Sept. 29, 2018, photo, Nebraska defensive coordinator Erik Chinander, right, follows an NCAA college football game against Purdue, in Lincoln, Neb. Chinander was a Hawkeye through and through as a kid growing up in eastern Iowa and as a walk-on offens… [+4045 chars]
fulltext:
In this Sept. 29, 2018, photo, Nebraska defensive coordinator Erik Chinander, right, follows an NCAA college football game against Purdue, in Lincoln, Neb. Chinander was a Hawkeye through and through as a kid growing up in eastern Iowa and as a walk-on offensive lineman and graduate of Iowa. Now he's a Cornhusker, the defensive coordinator at Nebraska, and he assures everyone he is not conflicted going into the game Friday at Kinnick Stadium in Iowa City. His parents and other family and friends will be there, too, and they'll all be wearing red. (AP Photo/Nati Harnik) (Photo: The Associated Press)

LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) — Erik Chinander was a Hawkeye through and through as a kid and then as a walk-on offensive lineman who earned two bachelor's degrees from Iowa.

He is the Nebraska defensive coordinator now, and as much as his eastern Iowa roots mean to him, he says he has no conflicted feelings heading into the Cornhuskers' final game at Kinnick Stadium in Iowa City on Friday.

"There's no doubt about it, I grew up in Iowa," Chinander said. "But home is where the heart is, and my home is in Lincoln, my heart is in Lincoln."

Chinander, 38, came with the rest of the Central Florida staff when Scott Frost was hired at Nebraska (4-7, 3-5 Big Ten) last December. Chinander and Frost have been together all but one year since they first worked together assistants at Northern Iowa a decade ago.

While Nebraska's spread-option offense has thrived with freshman quarterback Adrian Martinez, the defense has ranked near the bottom of the Big Ten in most statistics. The defense played its best game last Saturday when it held Michigan State under 300 yards in a 9-6 win, and Chinander said his charges will need to be at least as good against the Hawkeyes (7-4, 4-4).

"Obviously, it'll be good to go back to that stadium," Chinander said. "I got a lot of friends and family coming and wearing red to the game, so that'll be good. But this is an important game for our team. It's really important to finish strong and really important for the defense to play well this game and get some momentum going into the spring and recruiting."

Chinander has shared stories with linebacker Luke Gifford about his Iowa days, and Gifford said he senses this game is special to him.

"I know for us, as a defense, we want to go out there and play as well as we can, especially for him it would mean a lot," Gifford said.

Chinander is the son of longtime high school coach Gene Chinander, and Erik was a small-school all-state player at Allison-Bristow. He walked on at Iowa and made it onto the field for a handful of games as a backup offensive lineman. He lettered as a senior in 2002, when he also earned the Offensive Team Leader Award.

"I knew very early that I was much better at helping the other guys get lined up and do what they're supposed to do than actually doing it," Chinander said.

Chinander knew he wanted to go into coaching after finishing his degrees in history and health, leisure and sports studies. He spoke with coach Kirk Ferentz and other Iowa staff members about becoming a graduate assistant.

"Those guys all said we'd love to have you when there's an opening, but you probably need to get out and spread your wings and see some other stuff and we'll help you as much as we can," Chinander said. "And they helped me get some opportunities down the road that I got. The advice they gave me to spread my wings has been really good, and we haven't turned back and I'm glad where I'm at."

Chinander was an assistant at Ellsworth (Iowa) Community College in 2003 and coached the tight ends at Northern Iowa from 2004-09. Frost was on the UNI staff in 2007-08 before heading to Oregon.

Chinander was an Oregon intern in 2010 and graduate assistant in 2011-12 and left for a year to work with the Philadelphia Eagles' defensive line. He was back at Oregon as an assistant in 2014 and has been with Frost since.

Naturally, the two liked to reminisce about their college days — Frost at Nebraska and Chinander at Iowa.

"Now he's finally on the good side," Frost said.

___

author: USA TODAY, Adam Woodard, USA TODAY
title: The Match: Countless reasons why Tiger Woods vs. Phil Mickelson is a must-see event
description: From bets to the broadcast, Tiger Woods vs. Phil Mickelson is a must-see event, even if you have to pay for it. Something we have not seen before.
content: Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods shake hands during a press conference before The Match: Tiger vs Phil golf match at Shadow Creek Golf Course. (Photo: Kyle Terada, USA TODAY Sports) Thanksgiving is the perfect time to reflect on the year, spend time with loved … [+3004 chars]
fulltext:
Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods shake hands during a press conference before The Match: Tiger vs Phil golf match at Shadow Creek Golf Course. (Photo: Kyle Terada, USA TODAY Sports)

Thanksgiving is the perfect time to reflect on the year, spend time with loved ones, watch some football, and, of course, The Match between Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson.

At 3 p.m. ET on Friday at Las Vegas' beautiful and exclusive Shadow Creek, two of the greatest golfers not only of this generation but of all time will square off mano-a-mano in a match-play event for a $9 million prize. Many people, from USA TODAY Sports columnist Christine Brennan to four-time major champion Rory McIlroy, have said they don’t plan to watch The Match.

For the life of me, I can’t figure out why. This is something we have never seen before and might not see ever again.

The everyday sports fan will argue it’s $19.99 to watch golf on pay-per-view. They’ll say if an event like this were to happen, it should’ve been 10 years ago, when Woods and Mickelson weren’t well beyond their prime.

Sure, $19.99 may be a bit pricey for an event that could end in an hour if Tiger or Lefty dominate (or fall apart). But an event like this has never, and will never, take place again. Picture LeBron James and Kobe Bryant playing one-on-one.

That’s The Match.

Both players won a PGA Tour event last season. Mickelson won the World Golf Championships-Mexico Championship, an event where only the world's best qualify, and Woods won the Tour Championship, the final event of the Tour season featuring the year’s top 30 players.

Woods had seven top-10 finishes and 12 in the top 25. Mickelson had six and 15, respectively.

Not bad for past their prime.

The competition itself aside, how about the side bets?

Sponsors put up the $9 million prize, but Woods and Mickelson will pony up some of their own money on side bets throughout the competition, with all the money going to charity. On Tuesday, Mickelson baited Woods into a $200,000 bet that he will birdie the opening hole. Expect plenty more just like that.

Other expected bets will be long drive and closest-to-the-pin contests, with both players also likely proposing money challenges on putts and up-and-downs. The bets will likely be in the range of $10,000 to $50,000 per wager.

As if this match needed any more added pressure.

And last but not least, let’s talk about how incredible the broadcast will be.

Both players and their caddies will be wearing microphones. Drone coverage will deliver “camera angles that have never been seen before for a live golf event,” according to a Turner Sports press release. Real-time, hole-by-hole statistics on the screen will display the probability of different outcomes.

A one-hour pregame show will feature Charles Barkley, Samuel L. Jackson and PGA Tour player Pat Perez. Ernie Johnson will serve as the play-by-play announcer alongside former players Peter Jacobsen and Darren Clarke.

Barkley and Jackson are pure entertainment on their own. Perez is known on Tour for speaking his mind — especially about Tiger.

So while you’re sitting around on Friday afternoon, resting up after Thursday’s feast of food and football, tune in to The Match.

You won't see anything like it again.

Follow Adam Woodard on Twitter @AdamWoodard.

author: For The Win, Nick Schwartz, For The Win
title: Get Ya Popcorn: NFL celebrating touchdown antics that have gotten players fined
description: The NFL is policing touchdown celebrations while simultaneously advertising behavior it has punished in the past with a new Twitter account.
content: The NFL relaxed its rules on touchdown celebrations before the 2017 season, which has resulted in a long list of creative and hilarious moments that have gone viral on social media — but the league has still fined several players in 2018 for celebrations that… [+2520 chars]
fulltext:
The NFL relaxed its rules on touchdown celebrations before the 2017 season, which has resulted in a long list of creative and hilarious moments that have gone viral on social media – but the league has still fined several players in 2018 for celebrations that apparently crossed the line.

The league officially doesn’t want its players using outside props during TD celebrations, but it has no problem calling Joe Horn a “legend” for doing just that, as recently evidenced by a new NFL twitter account called @GetYaPopcorn.

2003: Joe Horn’s cell phone celebration

Joe Horn's a legend for this one 😂📞#GetYaPopcorn pic.twitter.com/KHRv2EXbwQ — Get Ya Popcorn (@GetYaPopcorn) November 17, 2018

Fine: $30,000, though it was Horn’s second violation that year. Earlier this season, the NFL hit New Orleans’ Michael Thomas with a $30,000 fine after he replicated Horn’s flip-phone celebration in a game against the Rams.

2005: Ochocinco’s pylon putt

Fine: $5,000, one of many Chad “Ochocinco” Johnson paid over the years. In 2009, Ochocinco said that he budgeted $100,000 to pay celebration fines during the season.

The @GetYaPopcorn account also features several videos of celebrations that have occurred since the rules were relaxed last year, along with a few classics.

Follow @GetYaPopcorn for the best celebrations in football 🍿 pic.twitter.com/PTzrYrSMtX — The Checkdown (@thecheckdown) November 20, 2018

Some fans and analysts have criticized the NFL for creating the account, pointing out that the league is still policing celebrations while simultaneously advertising behavior it has punished in the past.

Unbelievable.

The league once punished dudes for this now they’re monetizing it. https://t.co/RTs4IBvKJV — mike freeman (@mikefreemanNFL) November 21, 2018

title: Kosovo government gives financial reward to national team
description: Kosovo's government has decided to give a reward of 500,000 euros ($570,000) to the national soccer team as a reward for topping their group in the UEFA Nations League
content: TIRANA, Albania (AP) Kosovo's government has decided to give a reward of 500,000 euros ($570,000) to the national soccer team as a reward for topping their group in the UEFA Nations League and securing at least a playoff spot in qualifying for the 2020 Europe… [+550 chars]
fulltext:
TIRANA, Albania (AP) — Kosovo's government has decided to give a reward of 500,000 euros ($570,000) to the national soccer team as a reward for topping their group in the UEFA Nations League and securing at least a playoff spot in qualifying for the 2020 European Championship.

Kosovo, which declared independence from Serbia in 2008, has only been a UEFA and FIFA member since 2016.

The small Balkan republic routed Azerbaijan 4-0 in Pristina on Tuesday to win Group 3 of the lower-tiered League D and get promoted to League C for the next Nations League.

Playing in the playoffs could give Kosovo a shortcut to Euro 2020, which would be a huge sporting success for the country.

author: Brett Molina, USA TODAY
title: How this jellyfish earned the nickname 'Psychedelic Medusa'
description: Jellyfish called 'Psychedelic Medusa' intrigues scientists
content: Scientists discovered a jellyfish in such an unusual pose, they gave the creature a nickname: Psychedelic Medusa. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released footage of the jellyfish, a species called Crossota millsae, as part of its explorat… [+1039 chars]
fulltext:
CLOSE NOAA researchers spotted a unique medusa jellyfish hovering above the seafloor with its stinging tentacles extended off the coast of Puerto Rico. USA TODAY

A screenshot of the jellyfish species Crossota millsae, which scientists have nicknamed 'psychedelic Medusa.' (Photo: NOAA)

Scientists discovered a jellyfish in such an unusual pose, they gave the creature a nickname: Psychedelic Medusa.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released footage of the jellyfish, a species called Crossota millsae, as part of its exploration of deep-sea environments off the coasts of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Researchers captured the jellyfish, which appears pink and purple, with tentacles extended in all directions, believed to be "360-degree feeding."

"Certainly psychedelic, the video shows a jelly in a very interesting pose, suggesting this jellyfish may feed by hovering above the seafloor with stinging cell-loaded tentacles extended and waiting for prey," said Mike Ford of NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service and Smithsonian Environmental Research Center, in a blog post. "In other dives, these poses were followed by rapid swimming."

The jellyfish's pose was captured using a remote-operated vehicle (ROV) on the seafloor.

NOAA has encountered similar jellyfish before. Last year, the research vessel Okeanos Explorer grabbed footage of a jellyfish near American Samoa resembling a UFO.

Follow Brett Molina on Twitter: @brettmolina23.

author: Jay Johnson
title: Jags land QB Will Grier, OL Dalton Risner in 2019 mock draft - Jaguars Wire
description: Jaguars Wire Jags land QB Will Grier, OL Dalton Risner in 2019 mock draft Jaguars Wire With the Jacksonville Jaguars losing their sixth consecutive game Week 11 courtesy of the Pittsburgh Steelers, their playoff hopes going forward a simply very slim. That in…
content: With the Jacksonville Jaguars losing their sixth consecutive game Week 11 courtesy of the Pittsburgh Steelers, their playoff hopes going forward a simply very slim. That in mind, the fans can now turn their attention to the offseason in efforts to figure out … [+2602 chars]
fulltext:
With the Jacksonville Jaguars losing their sixth consecutive game Week 11 courtesy of the Pittsburgh Steelers, their playoff hopes going forward a simply very slim. That in mind, the fans can now turn their attention to the offseason in efforts to figure out what needs to be done to get the Jags back to being the Super Bowl contenders they were.

It’s clear that the Jags will need to invest a lot into their offense in 2019, and that process will begin in free agency. However, with the team projected to be over the cap, it appears they may not be able to be active like they’ve been in the past.

That then puts the Jags in a predicament where they’ll have to predominately sure up the offense in the draft, and that’s exactly what our comrade Luke Easterling has them doing in his latest Draft Wire mock. In it, the Jags were able to land two much-needed additions to the offense in West Virginia quarterback Will Grier and Kansas State tackle Dalton Risner.

6. Jacksonville Jaguars | Will Grier | QB | West Virginia Much like the Giants, the Jags need to move on from their current starting quarterback by replacing him with a top pick in this draft. Blake Bortles can’t be trusted to take advantage of one of the league’s best defenses, and though he’s not the only problem on offense, he’s the one that has the biggest impact. Grier is as worthy of a top-10 pick as any passer in this year’s class. 38. Jacksonville Jaguars | Dalton Risner | OL | Kansas State

Grier is a name climbing the ranks as a Heisman candidate due to the season he’s put together at West Virginia this year. He’s also someone who Jaguars fans are familiar with and are high on because he formerly played with the nearby Florida Gators. However, his tenure there was cut short after he was suspended for using a banned substance and he eventually transferred. Needless to say, this will be the biggest question and concern for him entering the draft.

As for his play on the field, the word I’ve often heard associated with him is “smooth” and from the games I’ve seen him play in that appears to be true. While there are some mechanical inconsistencies at times, his release is quick and he has the necessary arm strength to flourish in the NFL. He also puts his receivers in good position and has made some solid placement throws throughout the season.

Admittedly, I still need to watch more film on him, but he made a throw against Texas that caught the eyes of many and left fans intrigued.

VIDEO: West Virginia in the clutch! 🙌 Will Grier hits Gary Jennings for the late TD. 🚨 https://t.co/onxRNM7pXx pic.twitter.com/tTUxZ2VXcn — theScore (@theScore) November 3, 2018

As for Risner, he’s a player the Jags could desperately use for their struggling offense, too. At 6-foot-5, 308 pounds, he’s a force at the tackle position that can both stonewall defenders on the edge and maul them in the run game. Traits like that would greatly benefit whoever the Jags’ signal-caller is next year, whether that’s Blake Bortles, a free agent addition or a rookie like Grier.

title: Redskins-Cowboys Preview Capsule
description: Redskins-Cowboys Preview Capsule
content: WASHINGTON (6-4) at DALLAS (5-5) Thursday, 4:30 p.m. ET, Fox OPENING LINE Cowboys by 9 RECORD VS. SPREAD Redskins 7-3, Cowboys 5-5 SERIES RECORD Cowboys lead 70-45-2 LAST MEETING Redskins 20, Cowboys 17, Oct. 21 LAST WEEK Redskins lost to Texans 23-21; Cowboy… [+2995 chars]
fulltext:
WASHINGTON (6-4) at DALLAS (5-5)

Thursday, 4:30 p.m. ET, Fox

OPENING LINE — Cowboys by 9

RECORD VS. SPREAD — Redskins 7-3, Cowboys 5-5

SERIES RECORD — Cowboys lead 70-45-2

LAST MEETING — Redskins 20, Cowboys 17, Oct. 21

LAST WEEK — Redskins lost to Texans 23-21; Cowboys beat Falcons 22-19

AP PRO32 RANKING — Redskins No. 13; Cowboys No. 14

REDSKINS OFFENSE — OVERALL (25), RUSH (12), PASS (25)

REDSKINS DEFENSE — OVERALL (18), RUSH (6), PASS (24)

COWBOYS OFFENSE — OVERALL (27), RUSH (4), PASS (28)

COWBOYS DEFENSE — OVERALL (8), RUSH (5), PASS (11)

STREAKS, STATS AND NOTES — Could be swing game in division race, with Cowboys seeking tie for first and Redskins going for two-game lead, head-to-head sweep with five games remaining. ... Cowboys have won seven of eight Thanksgiving meetings between NFC East rivals. ... Both teams in top five in scoring defense: Cowboys third (19.0 points), Redskins fifth (19.8). ... Redskins making third straight Thanksgiving appearance and 11th overall. ... Redskins seeking franchise's 600th regular-season victory. Chicago (756), Green Bay (741), New York Giants (690), Pittsburgh (626) others with at least 600. ... Redskins have forced turnover in 14 straight games, longest active streak in NFL. They have at least three takeaways in three consecutive games for first time since 2003. ... With Redskins QB Alex Smith's season-ending leg injury, former Texas Longhorns star Colt McCoy making first start since Dec. 14, 2014, 24-13 loss to Giants. His last win as starter was 20-17 in OT at Cowboys on Oct. 27, 2014. McCoy was 25 of 30 for 299 yards. ... RB Adrian Peterson tied season high with two TDs rushing against Texans. He had 99 yards rushing in first Dallas meeting and needs two rushing TDs to pass Hall of Famer Jim Brown (106) for fifth on all-time list. ... TE Jordan Reed had 10 catches, 95 yards, two TDs in his last meeting with Cowboys in 2016. ... LB Ryan Kerrigan has 5½ sacks in past five games. ... Thanksgiving debut for Cowboys QB Dak Prescott and RB Ezekiel Elliott as rookies was 31-26 win over Redskins in 2016, team's 10th straight victory. ... Elliott has joined Hall of Famer Eric Dickerson and Edgerrin James as only backs with at least 4,500 yards from scrimmage and 30 touchdowns in first 35 games. Elliott has 4,540 yards, 32 TDs, including 388 yards, three touchdowns in past two games. ... Elliott missed Thanksgiving last season on six-game suspension over domestic violence allegations. ... Rookie WR Michael Gallup's status for game in question less than week after brother died by suicide. Gallup had first career touchdown in first meeting with Redskins. ... LB Leighton Vander Esch has interception in each of past two games. He set club rookie record with 19 tackles, according to coaches' count, in win at defending champion Philadelphia two games ago. ... DE DeMarcus Lawrence had 1½ sacks against Falcons, now third in NFL in sacks since start of last season with 22½. ... Fantasy tip: Elliott has consecutive 100-yard games, five for season. But Redskins haven't allowed 100-yard rusher this season.

___

author: Jets Wire
title: Revis: Brandon Marshall, Sheldon Richardson feud 'broke' Jets in 2016
description: It's no secret that Brandon Marshall and Sheldon Richardson did not get along in the Jets' locker room throughout the 2016 season. Beginning early in the season, the two developed a strong disdain for each other. For whatever reason, the two personalities cla…
content: It’s no secret that Brandon Marshall and Sheldon Richardson did not get along in the Jets’ locker room throughout the 2016 season. Beginning early in the season, the two developed a strong disdain for each other. For whatever reason, the two personalities cla… [+1344 chars]
fulltext:
It’s no secret that Brandon Marshall and Sheldon Richardson did not get along in the Jets’ locker room throughout the 2016 season.

Beginning early in the season, the two developed a strong disdain for each other. For whatever reason, the two personalities clashed and the end result was not pretty. Constant arguing in the locker room ensued and it was enough to throw the team off course, according to former Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis.

“I’ve never been a part of anything like that,” Revis said on WFAN Tuesday. “It was devastating. I kind of knew in a sense that it was going to be a very long season.”

As the season progressed, the Jets tried to fight through the locker room drama, but the damage had been done. With two cornerstone players going at it, the dynamic in the locker room had become too toxic for a veteran New York team to overcome.

“That kind of just broke us, that just broke our backbone as a team,” Revis said. “We tried to recover and it was an ongoing situation throughout the year, it never died down. We couldn’t bounce back from it.”

It’s clear that the beef between Marshall and Richardson led to an environment that no player wanted any part of. Throughout New York’s disappointing 5-11 2016 campaign, the Jets seemed lethargic on the field; it was as if they wanted to be anywhere else but playing the game.

One year after missing out on the playoffs, it had all fallen apart at 1 Jets Drive. Revis was part of the problem in 2016 with his awful play, but the constant fighting in the locker room didn’t do the team any favors.

author: Eli Blumenthal, USA TODAY
title: PS4, Xbox One or Nintendo Switch: Which console should you buy?
description: PlayStation, Xbox or Switch: Which should you buy?
content: One of the biggest staples of holiday sales aren't just the fancy new 4K TVs, it's what you can play on them. With Black Friday, Cyber Monday and just general holiday discounts abounding across retailers online and in-store, the Xbox One, PlayStation 4 and Ni… [+5950 chars]
fulltext:
PS4, Xbox One or Nintendo Switch: Which console should you buy?

(Photo: Getty Images)

One of the biggest staples of holiday sales aren't just the fancy new 4K TVs, it's what you can play on them.

With Black Friday, Cyber Monday and just general holiday discounts abounding across retailers online and in-store, the Xbox One, PlayStation 4 and Nintendo Switch all receive some of their biggest discounts this time of year, presenting an interesting challenge for buyers and gift givers: Which system should you choose?

While all can play "Fortnite" and "Minecraft," here is a guide to help you make this decision, plus a little bit of what you should keep in mind as we head into 2019.

For those on a budget: Xbox One S or PlayStation 4

PlayStation (Photo: Amazon)

At starting prices of $199.99, there are plenty of deals to be had for the Xbox One S or regular PlayStation 4. While not as powerful as their One X or PS 4 Pro siblings, both systems can play all the latest games and can even tap into newer TV features such as HDR.

Both consoles play largely the same games, including recent hits such as "Red Dead Redemption 2," "Madden 19," "NBA 2K19" and "Call of Duty Black Ops 4," but some exclusives such as "Marvel's Spider-Man" or "God of War" are only for PlayStation and franchises such as "Gears of War" and "Halo" are solely for Xbox.

More: Six helpful hints for your 'Red Dead Redemption 2' adventure

More: The best Black Friday Xbox deals of 2018

More: The best Black Friday PS4 deals of 2018

You can't really go wrong with either system, but if you are buying as a gift make sure to check with your gamer to find out where their friends play (and remember to pick up a subscription to Xbox Live or PlayStation Network, the respective service needed to play others online).

With the exception of "Fortnite," playing with friends on a different system is largely nonexistent right now.

If you have any gamers on your holiday shopping list, Walmart's got savings on consoles and games they'll love. (Photo: Microsoft)

The most recent PlayStation 4 is largely a cosmetic update to the original PS4 that was released in 2013. So if you already have a PS4 and are happy with it, this model isn't much of an upgrade. Both can play games in HDR.

More: Buying a new 4K HDR TV this holiday season? Read this first

Original Xbox One owners who find that system to be slow will, however, appreciate the One S, which isn't just sleeker but faster and more powerful than the first One and can play games in HDR and Blu-rays and Netflix in 4K.

As for which bundle – and there are plenty – to consider, look to see what each retailer offers. Games such as "Minecraft," 'NBA 2K19" or "Marvel's Spider-Man" are among the current popular titles being bundled, with some retailers also throwing in extra controllers and other perks.

Best for portable gamers: Nintendo Switch

Nintendo Switch (Photo: Nintendo)

While Nintendo's Switch lacks the graphical power of the Xbox One or PlayStation 4 and big releases such as "Madden," "Call of Duty" and "Red Dead Redemption 2," it does have a few perks of its own. The biggest: Portability.

Gamers play 'Super Smash Bros. Ultimate' on the Nintendo Switch. (Photo: Robert Deutsch, USAT)

With a built-in touch screen, the Switch can be used on its own or on a big TV when placed in its included docking station. The Joy-Con controllers can even be split up to let two players play a game such as "Mario Kart 8 Deluxe," "Super Mario Party" and the upcoming "Super Smash Bros. Ultimate" right out of the box.

On certain games, such as "Smash," up to eight players can play off of one Switch, assuming you have enough controllers to pass around.

More: First look: 'Super Smash Bros. Ultimate' brings the classic fight to the Switch

While Nintendo still sells its 3DS and 2DS portable systems, the latest lineup of new games – and the fact that the Switch can play "Fortnite" – make it a better option for many.

For the more intense gamers: Xbox One X or PlayStation 4 Pro

The best Black Friday Xbox deals of 2018 (Photo: Reviewed / Lee Neikirk)

If you just bought a fancy new 4K HDR TV and want to make the most of it, the Xbox One X or PlayStation 4 Pro are the options for you.

More: Buying a new 4K HDR TV this holiday season? Read this first

With improved graphical prowess and performance, both systems make games shine, particularly on 4K HDR TVs, which deliver improved resolution and colors over standard high-definition. Most of the more popular games released in 2018, including "Red Dead 2," "Spider-Man," and the latest versions of "Call of Duty," "Madden" and "NBA 2K," are optimized for 4K and HDR to make the most of what these systems offer.

(Photo: Sony.)

The Xbox One X is a bit more powerful, and at the moment is the same price as the PS4 Pro at $399. But again, it comes down to which games you want and what systems your friends use. As with their siblings, both are excellent consoles, and you won't be disappointed with either.

Be aware of 2019

Microsoft's first-party Xbox controller is still one of the best (Photo: Reviewed / Lee Neikirk)

As with other products such as AirPods, this year's game purchases have a cloud of uncertainty over them as major upgrades are rumored to be right around the corner.

While the Nintendo Switch launched only last year, rumors suggest Nintendo is readying an updated model possibly for next summer.

Both Sony and Microsoft have made clear that their next generation systems are in the works, with Sony most recently getting the internet talking that its decision to sit out the E3 video game conference next year is, in part, because it is working on the PlayStation 5. Rumors also are circulating that Sony might reveal the PS5 next year at its own event before releasing the new console in 2020.

At this year's E3, Microsoft's Xbox head Phil Spencer said the company's hardware team was already working on the "next Xbox consoles." Microsoft insider Brad Sams of Thurrott.com says the next-gen Xbox console is also expected in 2020.

Both consoles were released in November 2013, making each prime for an upgrade.

What does this mean for now? Not much in the short term as all current systems will continue to play great, with new games expected to come out for them over the next few years. But it is worth keeping mind what might be on the horizon, and when that horizon might arrive, as you prepare to shop this holiday season.

Follow Eli Blumenthal on Twitter @eliblumenthal

title: Italian players banned for match-fixing in 2011
description: Two Italian tennis players who previously were ranked in the top 50 have been banned for match-fixing at an ATP event in Barcelona in 2011
content: LONDON (AP) Two Italian tennis players who previously were ranked in the top 50 have been banned for match-fixing at an ATP event in Barcelona in 2011. Daniele Bracciali, who is still an active player, was banned for life and fined $250,000. Potito Starace, w… [+899 chars]
fulltext:
FILE - In this May 9, 2007 file photo, Italy's Daniele Bracciali returns the ball to Spain's Rafael Nadal at the Rome Masters tennis tournament at Rome's Foro Italico clay-court. The Tennis Integrity Unit announced the sanctions on Wednesday, Nov. 21, 2018, that two Italian tennis players, who previously were ranked in the top 50, Potito Starace and Daniele Braccali, have been banned for match-fixing at an ATP event in Barcelona in 2011. (AP Photo/Andrew Medichini, file) (Photo: The Associated Press)

LONDON (AP) — Two Italian tennis players who previously were ranked in the top 50 have been banned for match-fixing at an ATP event in Barcelona in 2011.

Daniele Bracciali, who is still an active player, was banned for life and fined $250,000. Potito Starace, who has retired, was banned from any future involvement in the sport for 10 years and fined $100,000.

The Tennis Integrity Unit announced the sanctions on Wednesday, following a disciplinary hearing in September.

The TIU says both players were found guilty of two breaches of anti-corruption rules. One relates to contriving the outcome of matches and the other relates to facilitating betting on matches.

The 40-year-old Bracciali is currently ranked No. 100 in doubles and had a career-high singles ranking of No. 49 in 2006. The 37-year-old Starace reached a career-best singles ranking of No. 27 in 2007.

As a doubles team, they reached the semifinals at the 2012 French Open.

author: USA TODAY Sports, USA TODAY Sports
title: USA TODAY Sports college football staff picks for Week 13
description: College football staff picks for Week 13 features rivalry games with playoff impact led by Ohio State-Michigan, Alabama-Auburn, Oklahoma-West Virginia.
content: USA TODAY Sports' Dan Wolken and Paul Myerberg react to the latest College Football Playoff rankings and ponder the chaos that could ensue if Georgia can upset Alabama in two weeks. USA TODAY Ohio State running back Mike Weber finds running room against Michi… [+2127 chars]
fulltext:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Dan Wolken and Paul Myerberg react to the latest College Football Playoff rankings and ponder the chaos that could ensue if Georgia can upset Alabama in two weeks. USA TODAY

Ohio State running back Mike Weber finds running room against Michigan during the second half of their game in 2017. (Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports)

Rivalry week is here which means intense games with College Football Playoff implications or bragging rights at stake.

In some cases, both are true.

The best illustration this week is when No. 4 Michigan paying a visit to No. 10 Ohio State. The Wolverines are hoping move closer to their first playoff appearance, while also winning in Columbus for the first time since 2000. But their archenemy stands in their way.

The Buckeyes, though, have not been playing well in the second half of the season, including last week's narrow win against Maryland. Their fortunes can change in 60 minutes, though, as a win would deny Michigan its first appearance in the Big Ten title game and give them the opportunity to play Northwestern with their playoff hopes still alive.

The three remaining Power Five unbeatens also have rivalry hurdles to contend with. No. 1 Alabama hosts Auburn. No. 2 Clemson gets a visit from South Carolina. And No. 3 Notre Dame travels to Southern California. All three look like manageable games. However, sometimes these showdowns don't go as expected.

Elsewhere, No. 6 Oklahoma and No. 12 West Virginia meet in Morgantown with a berth in the Big 12 championship game on the line. The Sooners still have playoff hopes, while the Mountaineers hope to bounce back from last week's loss to Oklahoma State that knocked them out of contention.

The Apple Cup has added significance this year as No. 7 Washington State has its sights set on more than just the Pac-12 title. The Cougars can stay in the playoff hunt, but have to reverse their run of disappointments against No. 16 Washington. The Huskies have won the last five meetings in dominant fashion and have the motivation of both denying their rivals their first trip to the conference title game, but also advancing themselves.

The last matchup of ranked opponents sees No. 15 Utah State and No. 22 Boise State square off for the Mountain division title in the Mountain West. The one-loss Aggies also have New Year's Six aspirations should Central Florida slip up.

author: For The Win, Michelle R. Martinelli, For The Win
title: Dale Earnhardt Jr. gives first season in TV booth a passing grade — but wants more
description: For The Win sat down with the NASCAR driver-turned-broadcaster to talk about his first season in the booth.
content: Dale Jr. and Chase Elliott (Jerry Markland/Getty Images) HOMESTEAD, Fla. - Dale Earnhardt Jr. retired almost exactly a year ago, but that retirement came with an asterisk. Even though he was leaving his No. 88 Chevrolet - although he still ran one race this y… [+8642 chars]
fulltext:
HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Dale Earnhardt Jr. retired almost exactly a year ago, but that retirement came with an asterisk. Even though he was leaving his No. 88 Chevrolet — although he still ran one race this year — he wasn’t leaving NASCAR.

The 15-time most popular driver transitioned out of the cockpit and into NBC’s broadcast booth, and he was on-air for the second half of the 36-race Cup Series season, along with Rick Allen, former driver Jeff Burton and Earnhardt’s former crew chief, Steve Letarte.

For The Win sat down with Earnhardt at Homestead-Miami Speedway and asked him to evaluate his own performance in his first season in the broadcast booth.

This interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.

What do you think you brought to the booth this year? You were hired to be yourself, so do you think you did that well?

My booth mates say I’ve come in with some good energy and revitalized them a little bit, and I’m happy hearing those comments and that’s what I wanted to do. I wanted to come in with a real fan type of happiness and joy for what I’m watching, and I feel like I’ve been able to do that. That’s gonna be something that’s important for me to maintain for however many more years I do this. That’s probably the most important attribute I have — that fandom, that passion for it. So as long as I got that, I think I’ll be in good shape.

But the nerves have come down, which has allowed me to be a bit more of myself. I’m nowhere near nervous as I used to be.

Did you have an advantage starting in the booth for the second half of the season, as opposed to working with FOX Sports and broadcasting the first half?

Man, I don’t know. Starting with Daytona would have been pretty awesome. I had a chance to go into the FOX booth and work The Clash in 2017, and Speedweeks to me is a really special time of year. So being able to call the Daytona 500 would be a real dream of mine. I think it would be for any of us in the booth — Rick, Burton and Steve.

I would have been much more nervous than I was going into Chicago, so it’s kind of fun hopping in the middle of the season. And we had an incredible race, which made it a lot easier on me. So I’m glad we get to call the final event, I’m glad we call the playoffs. It really emphasizes the responsibility you have as a broadcaster to build up those storylines and carry the fans all the way to the finish, talking about what’s happening and who’s doing what. You’re invested in it because you know you’ll be there for the final race.

Nothing quite like @NASCAR racing. Gets you pumped for Daytona this weekend, doesn’t it? pic.twitter.com/Tm6tamaWd3 — NASCAR on NBC (@NASCARonNBC) July 3, 2018

How would you grade your job performance at the end of your first season?

There’s awesome days and not so awesome days. There’s little stretches during the race where I’m real frustrated with what I’m doing and frustrated that I’m not able to get in the moment with the guys.

Steve and Jeff and Rick are so used to working together. So much time spent together that they just can go and it seems like they work very well together, and me trying to fit myself into that comfortable puzzle they have. And they’ve been great about it. They’ve been very helpful to allow me the confidence to jump in. It’s like double-dutch.

There’s times when I’ll have a little good stretch during the broadcast, and I’ll think, “Man, I really happy with what I just did.” And then there’s times I’ll say things or talk about stuff and I’ll go, “Was that really just babble?” or “Was that really critical information?”

So what type of grade does that amount to?

I’m hesitant to do that, hesitant to give myself a grade. I would say that judging by the reaction from social media, people seem pleased. I know a lot of people follow me because they’re fans of mine, so it’s going to be positive feedback. But I’ve had people come up to me and tell me, “I didn’t think it would work, but you won me over.”

I’ve had industry people tell me they love me in the booth. Crew chiefs of other drivers, guys in the NASCAR organization, come up to me and say I’m helping. So I would give myself a passing grade. But everyone has a preference. Some people say you scream too much, some people say you don’t scream enough. It’s not a win for everybody.

Joey Logano beats Martin Truex Jr. off pit road, but Kevin Harvick beats them . both! Less than 33 laps remaining on NBC. #NASCARPlayoffs pic.twitter.com/Fgfwrdy6Zf — NASCAR on NBC (@NASCARonNBC) November 18, 2018

What’s been the best part of your first season broadcasting?

The best part of broadcasting is when we are talking about a battle on the race track. For example, if you go back and watch the Roval (race from September at Charlotte Motor Speedway), there was a moment where Brad Keselowski and Kyle Larson had a battle for a couple laps, and me and Jeff Burton were just talking through the laps with what we were seeing.

And those moments when it’s me and someone else in the booth discussing the battle on the track between two competitors and talking about the lines they’re choosing and why they do this and that, and what I expect them to do in the next corner and you get it right — those are the funnest times. That’s when the adrenaline’s really going, and you’re a fan at that point.

And the most challenging part?

The most challenging part is the front of the show, the produced part. There’s 10 minutes when we’re going through ceremonies and on camera. It’s scripted, and it’s prepared, and that’s when you’re trying to remember your points. And you think about it too much. Instead of just being yourself and reacting to someone else’s comments, you’re preparing what you’re going to say.

And it never comes off the way it sounds in your head. It never sounds as good as you hope, but it’s never as bad as it sounds either. That’s one of the funny things I found out about broadcasting.

For some drivers, tonight might be their last chance to earn their spot in the #NASCARPlayoffs. DAYTONA. NBC. Stream: https://t.co/WTwvY7sMVl pic.twitter.com/RnwiZIT0Cl — NASCAR on NBC (@NASCARonNBC) July 7, 2018

You had been in the booth for a select few races before, so doing it full-time, was there anything you didn’t realize you’d need to learn?

A lot of times, you’ll have an idea and you can’t get it in. We have a talk-back button to the producer. So I’ve had to get very comfortable and almost aggressive to hit that button and tell the producer, “I have a point here I’d like to mention. I’d like to come in at the back end of whoever’s talking to add to the point.”

So when I first got in there, I thought we just talked. But no, I’ve got to tell my producer, “Hey, I could add to this,” and that’s what we’re doing all day long, because if they don’t know that, they won’t make room for you. They told me when I came in, “You’re going to get real friendly with this talk-back button. Don’t be afraid to use it.” I didn’t really know what they meant until later on in the game.

Where would you like to see yourself improve next season and beyond?

It’s almost like when the green flag drops, you forget you’re on TV. You do, and you’re not nervous. You’re just talking to your buddies about the race. You’re just talking to Jeff about what’s happening. But in the opening when we’re on camera, you can’t shake the feeling that everybody’s watching and you’re on camera and it’s uncomfortable.

It’s rare that we have a chance to take us to commercial or bring us in from commercial. Rick, obviously, that’s his role. Sometimes the producer will say, “All right, Jeff, you’re going to take us to commercial.” I don’t get those opportunities because I’m not very efficient at it, but I would love to be able to get comfortable doing those type of things. I told NBC when I got hired, “Man, I really wanna be the kind of guy you could put in any position in that booth and you’d feel comfortable and confident in me.”

I really wanna learn every part of it to where I can be that guy. Like if Rick were to fall ill, and they’re like, “Who’s gonna be the guy?” I wanna be that guy. It’s not gonna happen today or tomorrow, next year or the year after that. But maybe four, five, six years down the road, I would have enough experience and they would have enough confidence in me that I could fill that role if needed. I want to work on being the total package.

author: USA TODAY, Hannah Yasharoff, USA TODAY
title: Prince William describes how his mental health changed: 'I got very sad and very down'
description: Prince William revealed how becoming a parent affected his mental health at work. The royal left his job as an air ambulance pilot last summer.
content: Britain's Prince William and Duchess Kate with their children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis as they arrive for Prince Louis' christening service on July 9 in London. (Photo: Dominic Lipinski, AP) Prince William has become an outspoken adv… [+2242 chars]
fulltext:
Prince William describes how his mental health changed: 'I got very sad and very down'

Prince William has become an outspoken advocate for mental health awareness in recent years. Now he's speaking out about how his own mental health changed when he became a parent.

During a panel Tuesday in London about mental health in the workplace, the father of three explained that the heaviness of his former job as an air ambulance pilot had a lasting toll, particularly when he was responding to emergencies involving other children.

William is the father of Prince George, 5, Princess Charlotte, 3 and Prince Louis, 6 months.

“The relation between the job and the personal life was what really took me over the edge," he said, according to People and Entertainment Tonight. "And I started feeling things that I’ve never felt before. And I got very sad and very down about this particular family,” he said. “You start to take away bits of the job and keep them in your body."

More: Prince William, Lady Gaga discuss mental health

More: Prince William tackles mental health stigma on Fathers's Day

He continued, stressing the importance of workplaces providing proper mental health resources for their employees.

"You don’t want to share with your loved ones because you just don’t want to bring that sort of stuff home,” Prince William said. “So the only place you can talk about it is at work and if you don’t necessarily have the right tools or the right environment at work, you can see why things can snowball and get quite bad.”

"Just as we look after our physical health, we need to look after our #MentalHealth." — The Duke of Cambridge, speaking at the 2018 This Can Happen Conference. #ThisCanHappen18pic.twitter.com/Sa6t2bTKjz — Kensington Palace (@KensingtonRoyal) November 20, 2018

He then called on workplaces to set a "culture of this open, understanding, supportive environment."

"We could really use some more voices in the workplace," he said. "Standing up and saying, 'Yeah, I've been there. I've done that and I could have done more' ... I think that's really important."

William stepped down from his post as air ambulance pilot last summer to become a full-time royal.

Read or Share this story: https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2018/11/21/prince-william-got-very-sad-and-very-down-mental-health-struggle-work-parenting/2077730002/

author: AP, AP
title: Panthers' Trocheck has surgery for fractured ankle
description: Florida Panthers forward Vincent Trocheck has had surgery for a fractured ankle and may play again this season
content: TAMPA, Fla. (AP) Florida Panthers forward Vincent Trocheck has had surgery for a fractured ankle and may play again this season. Trocheck was hurt when twisted his right leg while chasing the puck near the end boards in Monday night's game at Ottawa. He was t… [+767 chars]
fulltext:
TAMPA, Fla. (AP) — Florida Panthers forward Vincent Trocheck has had surgery for a fractured ankle and may play again this season.

Trocheck was hurt when twisted his right leg while chasing the puck near the end boards in Monday night's game at Ottawa. He was taken off the ice on a stretcher.

"It's never easy to see a player and person like him suffer an injury like this, but we are confident that he will make a full recovery and be back on the ice with our team this season," Panthers general manager Dale Tallon said in a statement Wednesday.

The 2017 NHL All-Star has three goals and 14 points in 18 games this season.

Trocheck tweeted "surgery was a success" and "I'll be back before you know it."

Florida recalled forward Denis Malgin from Springfield of the AHL in advance of Wednesday night's game at Tampa Bay.

___

author: USA TODAY, Lorenzo Reyes, USA TODAY
title: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones says Amari Cooper has had a Michael Irvin-like effect
description: Cowboys owner Jerry Jones says that the addition of Amari Cooper has aided the rushing game like it did when Michael Irvin was on the team.
content: Cowboys wide receiver Amari Cooper has one touchdown since joining the Cowboys on Oct. 22. (Photo: Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports) By adding Amari Cooper one month ago, the Dallas Cowboys, at least theoretically, have opened up the offense more -- especially i… [+2205 chars]
fulltext:
Cowboys wide receiver Amari Cooper has one touchdown since joining the Cowboys on Oct. 22. (Photo: Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports)

By adding Amari Cooper one month ago, the Dallas Cowboys, at least theoretically, have opened up the offense more -- especially in the running game.

But even though they have gone 2-1 since acquiring Cooper, the Cowboys' offense has improved only marginally. They have averaged 21 points (compared to 20 in the first seven games) and 343 yards (compared to 320).

Cooper has 14 catches for 169 yards and one touchdown.

That still hasn't stopped Cowboys owner Jerry Jones from comparing the effect of Cooper to Cowboys and Hall of Fame receiver Michael Irvin, who played alongside fellow Hall of Famers in quarterback Troy Aikman and running back Emmitt Smith in the early 1990s.

“Emmitt had a lot of his runs where he wasn't touched for the first three or four yards,” Jones said on a Wednesday appearance on NFL Network. “It's because Aikman and Irvin had them backed off, and they knew if they didn't stay back then Aikman, Irvin and (tight end Jay) Novacek would take them right down the field.

“Well, Cooper has done that for us. We got to keep them backed off. When we do, then (running back Ezekiel Elliott) can basically have the kind of days we want him to have as a running back. So it's a balance thing -- it always has been.”

More: 14 NFL records that could be broken by end of 2018 season

More: NFL QB Hot Sheet: Is Lamar Jackson ready to take over for Ravens?

Elliott has rushed for two of his five touchdowns over the past three weeks. He has averaged 5.7 yards per carry since Cooper arrived compared to 4.6 before the receiver's arrival. Since Week 8 when Cooper was acquired, Elliott has led the league in rushing by averaging 111.3 yards.

Earlier this season, Jones compared the Cowboys' offense to that of the Los Angeles Rams, who rank second in scoring and beat the Kansas City Chiefs 54-51 on Monday. But on Wednesday he said that the Cowboys strive for balance.

“We won't play the same kind of game that you saw the other night on Monday Night Football – what a game,” Jones continued. “But our game is going to be a more balanced between the run and the pass, but you got to get them both going to make it work. Our defense is better than any defense we've had in the last few years as well.”

The 5-5 Cowboys play a pivotal NFC East game against the 6-4 Washington Redskins on Thanksgiving.

Where would you like to see yourself improve next season and beyond?

It’s almost like when the green flag drops, you forget you’re on TV. You do, and you’re not nervous. You’re just talking to your buddies about the race. You’re just talking to Jeff about what’s happening. But in the opening when we’re on camera, you can’t shake the feeling that everybody’s watching and you’re on camera and it’s uncomfortable.

It’s rare that we have a chance to take us to commercial or bring us in from commercial. Rick, obviously, that’s his role. Sometimes the producer will say, “All right, Jeff, you’re going to take us to commercial.” I don’t get those opportunities because I’m not very efficient at it, but I would love to be able to get comfortable doing those type of things. I told NBC when I got hired, “Man, I really wanna be the kind of guy you could put in any position in that booth and you’d feel comfortable and confident in me.”

I really wanna learn every part of it to where I can be that guy. Like if Rick were to fall ill, and they’re like, “Who’s gonna be the guy?” I wanna be that guy. It’s not gonna happen today or tomorrow, next year or the year after that. But maybe four, five, six years down the road, I would have enough experience and they would have enough confidence in me that I could fill that role if needed. I want to work on being the total package.

author: USA TODAY, Gabe Lacques, USA TODAY
title: Brewers could be a perfect dark horse fit for Bryce Harper
description: Coming off a 96-win season and a trip to the NLCS, the Milwaukee Brewers could make a splash by adding another MVP to their lineup.
content: Harper is one of the top free agents on the market. (Photo: USA TODAY Sports) Bryce Harper, a National League MVP at 23, is a free agent at 26, peddling his services in an industry that’s grown to nearly $11 billion in annual revenues. His combination of skil… [+5348 chars]
fulltext:
Harper is one of the top free agents on the market. (Photo: USA TODAY Sports)

Bryce Harper, a National League MVP at 23, is a free agent at 26, peddling his services in an industry that’s grown to nearly $11 billion in annual revenues. His combination of skills, age and marketing cachet make him an excellent fit for any major league franchise.

Including the Milwaukee Brewers.

Harper, who has 184 career home runs and a lifetime .900 OPS, rejected a 10-year, $300 million contract offer from the Washington Nationals in September, and is a good bet to set a new standard for the most lucrative contract in North American sports history.

It may take weeks for that process to play out. In the meantime, USA TODAY Sports will examine why every team could use Harper’s services – some more than others, certainly some better-equipped to procure them.

A case for Harper and the Brewers joining forces:

On the field

We all deserve to splurge every now and again. And the Milwaukee Brewers have earned the right to treat themselves.

General manager David Stearns – and his predecessor, Doug Melvin – helmed a re-tooling that produced impact players at friendly prices. And in an era where several franchises struggle to extract themselves from “tanking” mode, Stearns hit the afterburners at just the right time.

His signing of outfielder Lorenzo Cain and acquisition of Christian Yelich last January could not have gone better: Yelich and Cain ranked 1-2 in National League position player Wins Above Replacement. Yelich went on to win NL MVP.

And the Brewers’ season lasted all the way to Game 7 of the NL Championship Series, falling just a few innings shy of their first World Series berth since 1982.

Most notably, Stearns assembled this core with a significant amount of cost certainty.

The five-year, $80 million deal given to Cain now looks like a bargain. For now, the mere cost of prospects to acquire Yelich has not yet come back to bite the Brewers.

And for the next four seasons, they will have the 2018 NL MVP in their lineup for the low cost of $12.8 million per season.

In the big picture, they’d be spending some $35 million per season on Harper – say, 12 years and $420 million. In the near term, they could view it as paying one of the greatest outfields of all time – two NL MVPs and a world class center fielder - an average of $21.2 million per man.

Not bad, eh?

More cash will loosen up after 2020, when the last of the $40 million guaranteed Ryan Braun falls off the books. In the meantime, they can shift Braun to first base and perhaps deal Jesus Aguilar – at the height of his value - to an American League team.

And if Yelich enjoyed the boost in production moving from Marlins to Miller Park, imagine the bounce Harper might receive.

While Harper’s Nationals Park rated better last season as a home run haven (1.17 per game, park-adjusted, to Miller’s 1.12), the Brewers’ home stadium is far better for power hitters as the data set grows. Twice this decade it’s led the majors in home run indulgence.

Yelich, who also made some key tweaks to his swing, doubled his home run output from 18 to 36 while playing in nine fewer games in 2018. It’s not hard to imagine a 26-year-old Harper toppling his career best of 42 homers – particularly surrounded by Cain, Yelich, Braun and Travis Shaw.

Off the field

You’d think nearly making the World Series would’ve let everyone in on this secret, but here it is again: Milwaukee is a phenomenal baseball town.

The Brewers ranked sixth in the NL in attendance, and 11th overall, drawing 2.85 million and boosting their average crowd by nearly 4,000, to 35,000. Adding Harper to a club coming off 96 wins would surely push them past their franchise record of 3.07 million, set in 2011, and further cement their relevance in an area that also has eyes for Aaron Rodgers and Giannis Antetokounmpo.

As for Harper, setting up shop in Milwaukee would certainly test the notion of whether baseball is truly a “national” sport, and not a collection of regional interests. Harper would be moving from the USA’s sixth-largest media market to No. 36.

At this point, however, Harper’s brand is well-established. So long as the Brewers continue winning, his exposure will maintain – and his mere presence would compel the networks to feature them in national broadcasts. (With 19 games per year against the Cubs, you can already see the Kris Bryant-Harper promo graphic, right?)

Why they could pull it off

With a franchise value of $1.03 billion and annual revenues of $255 million, according to Forbes, the Brewers have the cash. In fact, they’ve now moved up two slots, to No. 25, in franchise value, and have appreciated nicely since owner Mark Attanasio bought the club for $223 million in 2005.

Still, their market limitations are real. That brings us back to Stearns and his front-office lieutenants: They chased down the Cubs in September with Wade Miley, Jhoulys Chacin, Chase Anderson, Junior Guerra, Zach Davies and others comprising their rotation down the stretch. None made more than $7 million last season.

They got within one game of the World Series with a mélange of Miley, Gio Gonzalez, Chacin and reliever Brandon Woodruff starting playoff games.

In short, the Brewers know how to contain costs with creativity. A Saks Fifth Avenue lineup paired with a pitching staff purchased at Kohl’s might look odd – but it can work.

Will it happen?

Not terribly likely. Make no mistake: Dark horses will surely emerge before the Harper sweepstakes wrap up and the Brewers fit that profile – but probably not as snugly as others.

author: USA TODAY, Rasha Ali, USA TODAY
title: The Rock's daughter insists on painting her father's face before he leaves for work
description: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson's daughter won't let her dad leave for work without painting his face.
content: Dwayne Johnson as Spencer in 'Ballers.' (Photo: Jeff Daly, HBO, Jeff Daly, HBO) Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson's daughter was feeling a little artsy Wednesday morning. Her canvas of choice? Her father's face. The "Jumanji" star shared a photo on his Instagram of h… [+1664 chars]
fulltext:
The Rock's daughter insists on painting her father's face before he leaves for work

Dwayne Johnson as Spencer in 'Ballers.' (Photo: Jeff Daly, HBO, Jeff Daly, HBO)

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson's daughter was feeling a little artsy Wednesday morning. Her canvas of choice? Her father's face.

The "Jumanji" star shared a photo on his Instagram of his 2-year-old daughter Jasmine ever so carefully holding a paintbrush to his nose, seemingly adding the finishing touches to her masterpiece.

Johnson said as he was saying goodbye to his daughter, she told him she needed to paint his toes before he left for work. He declined her offer because he already had his shoes on.

Shoes proved to be a minor inconvenience for Jasmine as she quickly changed course and said she'd just paint his face instead. Despite his demurral, his daughter's "intoxicating blue eyes" made him think twice and he finally gave in.

The two came to a compromise: She could paint his face as long as she chose "manly" colors that complemented his complexion.

Based on Jasmine's choices of yellow and green, maybe was photographed during the color-correction stage of doing her dad's face?

author: redmondso
title: Top 10 NFL Thanksgiving moments
fulltext:
None

7. Bounty Bowl I, 1989: So much for the Philadelphia Eagles and Dallas Cowboys playing nice on Thanksgiving. During the Eagles’ 27-0 rout, they also managed to knock kicker Luis Zendejas out of the game, leading Cowboys coach Jimmy Johnson to accuse Eagles coach Buddy Ryan of placing bounties on Zendejas and quarterback Troy Aikman. The vitriol between the coaches set up what was known as “Bounty Bowl II” two weeks later in Philadelphia, where refs, Cowboys coaches and players and broadcasters were all pelted with snowballs. Brad Bower ASSOCIATED PRESS

author: AP, AP
title: No. 17 Kentucky tries to reach 9 wins for 1st time since '83
description: No. 17 Kentucky seeks 2nd win in 3 years against archrival Louisville and a 9-win season for first time since 1983
content: Kentucky linebacker Josh Allen (41) pressures Middle Tennessee quarterback Brent Stockstill (12) during the second half of an NCAA college football game against Kentucky in Lexington, Ky., Saturday, Nov. 17, 2018. (AP Photo/Bryan Woolston) (Photo: The Associa… [+2445 chars]
fulltext:
Kentucky linebacker Josh Allen (41) pressures Middle Tennessee quarterback Brent Stockstill (12) during the second half of an NCAA college football game against Kentucky in Lexington, Ky., Saturday, Nov. 17, 2018. (AP Photo/Bryan Woolston) (Photo: The Associated Press)

No. 17 Kentucky (8-3, No. 15 CFP) at Louisville (2-9), 7 p.m. EST (ESPN2).

Line: Kentucky by 16½.

Series record: Series tied at 15.

WHAT'S AT STAKE?

The winner claims the Governor's Cup and Bluegrass bragging rights. Having secured a third consecutive bowl berth, the Wildcats seek their most regular-season wins since 1977 and second series victory in three years. The Cardinals seek to end an eight-game losing streak with their seventh series win in eight meetings.

KEY MATCHUP

Kentucky RB Benny Snell Jr. vs. Louisville's run defense. The junior has surpassed 1,000 yards rushing for the third consecutive season (1,205, second in the SEC) and is 207 away from breaking Sonny Collins' school record of 3,835 from 1972-75. Snell rushed for 211 yards on 29 carries last year in Lexington and will face a unit that ranks 125th nationally at 271.6 yards allowed per game.

PLAYERS TO WATCH

Kentucky: LB Josh Allen. The senior posted a career-best 15 tackles, including two critical sacks late to preserve the Wildcats' 34-23 win over Middle Tennessee. In the process he broke school sack records for a single season (13) and career (27½). Allen could pad his numbers even more against an offense that has yielded an ACC-worst 41 sacks this season.

Louisville: QB Malik Cunningham. Whether he or Jawon Pass start will be a game-time decision, but the redshirt freshman leads the Cardinals with 408 yards rushing, including 100 on eight carries in last week's loss to N.C. State. He and 2016 Heisman Trophy winner Lamar Jackson are the only QBs in school history to rush for at least 100 yards twice. Jackson did it 23 times.

FACTS & FIGURES

Snell is Kentucky's career leader in rushing and total TDs with 44. ... The Wildcats rank 12th nationally in scoring defense (16.8 points per game) and 24th in total defense (328.2 yards). ... Louisville will say goodbye to 11 seniors who have gone 27-23 and reached three bowl games in their careers. ... The Cardinals are coming off a 52-10 loss to North Carolina State, the sixth time this season it has allowed at least 50 points. ... The game marks the second for Cardinals interim coach Lorenzo Ward, who took over when Bobby Petrino was fired on Nov. 11.

___

More AP college football: https://apnews.com/tag/Collegefootball and https://twitter.com/AP_Top25
